channel.title: Red Hat Issue Tracker
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [SWATCH-3545] Conflict resolution periodically creates incorrect amendment event
item.description:
This bug is currently only occurring periodically during during test runs.

https://ibutsu.insights.corp.redhat.com/project/3915c900-85fc-1222-833c-10d51af56f2e/results/db387c9e-d5e5-4573-9202-79cf6f8605e5#summary

After evaluating the logs from a test failure, it appears that the events API is not returning the expected events from the DB after triggering conflict resolution. 

Numerous attempts to reproduce against a local deployment and via IQE have failed. This bug feels like it could be a subtle date issue when determining the latest event to resolve.

 

Test Steps

All test event messages should have the same org_id, instance_id, product tag, and timestamp. This is what will trigger the conflict resolution logic.

  1. Send an event with a measurement of: cores: 1.0
    • An event record will be created: cores: 1.0
  2. Send an event with a measurement of: cores: 10.0
    • Original event will remain: cores: 1.0
    • And amendment event will be created: cores: -1.0
    • An event will be created with the new value: cores: 10.0
  3. Send an event with a measurement of: cores: 100.0
    • Existing events will remain:
      • cores: 1.0
      • cores: -1.0
      • cores: 10.0
    • A new amendment event is created
      • Expected result
        • cores: -10.0
      • NOTE: This is where the test fails. It will instead result in an amendment event with measurement
        • cores: -1.0
    • An new event will be created for the incoming value:
      • cores: 100

 

Here's a python script that I had used when trying to reproduce this locally. It will perform the test steps against a local deployment and mimic what the test was doing against IQE. It will continuously run the scenario and attempt to trigger/identify the error.

test_conflict_resolution.py

 

Spot Checking the DB

After spot checking some data in production and stage DBs, I didn't find any evidence of this occuring. That said, gabi was timing out, so I had to do some spot checking.

To do this, you'll need to identify an org that has events with amendments present.

select distinct(org_id), count(*) from events where data->>'amendment_type' = 'deduction' group by org_id

Target in on events with a matching deduction events for a particular org:

select instance_id, record_date, timestamp from events where org_id='YOUR_ORG_ID' and data->>'amendment_type'='deduction' order by instance_id, record_date

Select a single instance_id and timestamp from the results above, and isolate the event set that includes the amendment event.

select record_date, timestamp, data->'measurements'->0 from events where org_id='YOUR_ORG_ID' and instance_id='YOUR_INSTANCE_ID' and timestamp='YOUR_TIMESTAMP' order by record_date

 

 

Acceptance Criteria

  • Cause of the issue is identified, hopefully with a reproducer.
  • Bug fix added to swatch.
item.summary: Conflict resolution periodically creates incorrect amendment event

comments.comment:
Lindsey Burnett mentioned this issue in merge request !1273 of insights-qe / iqe-rhsm-subscriptions-plugin on branch lburnett/SWATCH-3545:

Draft: WIP

This bug is caused by a combination of transaction isolation issues and flawed intra-batch conflict resolution logic. The bug manifested as inappropriate deduction events being created when multiple events with the same conflict key arrived in the same Kafka batch, leading to cascading deductions that corrupted billing calculations.

See https://docs.google.com/document/d/1CPc3U4QGUZYbXuPAJbd_zI5G0fRw2enAlI3yfh-sb78/edit?tab=t.ttyyd8vebnmg for complete analysis and details
